CatDescriptText: Mrs. Edith Williams, Hill District and Mrs. William Cuthbert, civic worker, Penn Hills, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 27, 1962, pg. 12 with question: "What is the most important issue confronting Pittsburgh in 1962?" Mrs. Williams' answer reads: "I do think there could be more advantages for both races. In other words, we should try to get along better and understand each other better."  Mrs. Cuthbert's answer reads: "The most pressing issue, I think, is adequate housing for all people.  I'm talking about both moderated and low-income private housing."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Edith Williams wearing head scarf, eyeglasses, and light colored coat with mismatched buttons, standing on sidewalk in front of building; Portrait of Mrs. William Cuthbert  wearing dark satin hat with feather and Persian lamb coat with fur collar, standing on sidewalk in front of building with sign that reads "Polaroid"
